summary.value:
Provide a narrative summary of what is contained in this registration, or how it differs from prior registrations.

Hypotheses: What's the main question being asked or hypothesis being tested in this study?

We are interested in understanding the factors that lead to solidarity across members of different minority groups. In doing so, we are particularly interested in investigating the role that perceptions of similarity across minority groups might play in producing solidarity. 

In our current study, we manipulate the racial composition of a group of individuals and ask participants (all Black U.S. citizens) a set of questions about the attitudes they hold towards these groups. Specifically, we hypothesize that Black participants will be more likely to express solidarity with a group comprised of Latino and White individuals compared to a group composed of Asian and White people. 
						
Dependent Variable: Describe the key dependent variable(s) specifying how they will be measured.	

Primary Outcome Variables:

The questions below refer to the picture presented in the stimulus materials (see below under “Conditions” for details).

Solidarity (Leach et al., 2008)
I feel a bond with these group members. 
I feel solidarity with these group members.
I feel committed to these group members. 

Inclusion of others in the self (Aron et al, 1992)
Prompt: Which picture best describes your relationship with the image of the individuals in the image above? In the pictures below, the SELF represents you and OTHER represents the team of managers. 
 


Below is a list of variables we view as likely to function as mediators of our predicted effect:

Identification scale (Ellemers et al., 1997), 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree)
Prompt: Given the picture above, please rate this picture with the following questions:
I identify with the individuals from this group
I see myself as someone from this group
I feel strong ties with the individuals from this group

Sense of executive belonging (adapted from Brands and Fernandez-Mateo, 2016)
If you join these group members….
I feel that I belong to this group.
I consider myself a member of this group.
I feel like I am part of this group.
I feel a connection with this group.
I feel like I fit in.
I feel like an outsider (–).
I feel respected
I feel valued
I feel accepted.
I feel appreciated.
I feel disregarded (–).
I feel neglected (–).
I feel excluded (–).
I feel insignificant (–).
I feel at ease.
I feel comfortable.
I feel content.
I feel calm
I feel anxious (–).
I feel tense (–).
I feel nervous (–).
I feel inadequate (–).
I enjoy being an active participant.
I wish I were invisible (–).
I wish I could fade into the background and not be noticed (–).
Try to say as little as possible (–).
I trust the recruitment and selection procedures to be unbiased.
I have trust that I do not have to constantly prove myself.
I trust my mentors to be committed to helping me develop.
Even when I do poorly, I trust my mentors to have faith in my potential.

Linked Fate (Ho, Kteily, and Chen, 2017) 
○	I feel a sense of common destiny with the people in this group.
○	Issues that affect the members of this group also affect me.
○	What happens to the people in this group does not have anything to do with what happens to me (reverse-scored)
○	Racial progress for me also means racial progress for the people in this group.
○	When the way people like me are treated in the U.S. changes, the way that people in this group are treated will naturally follow.

Status Anderson et al. (2001): (1 = much less than others, 7 = much more than others)
Compared to others in the organization…
How much respect do you believe this team has?
How much status do you believe this team has?
How much admiration do you believe this team has?

Competence and Warmth Scales (Fiske, Cuddy, Glick and Xu, 2002)
Prompt: to what extent to do think that society views the type of individuals in this group as having these traits...
Competence: As viewed by society, how . . . are members of this group?
[competent, confident, capable, efficient, intelligent, skillful]
Status: 
How prestigious are the jobs typically achieved by members of this group? 
How economically successful have members of this group been?
Competition: 
If members of this group get special breaks (such as preference in hiring decisions), this is likely to make things more difficult for people like me. 
Resources that go to members of this group are likely to take away from the resources of people like me.

Perceived diversity (Unzueta and Binning, 2012) 
This team includes a high degree of ethnic diversity
I consider this team to be ethnically diverse
This team includes a low degree of ethnic diversity [reverse coded] 

We also plan to measure two potential moderators:

We expect that the effects we predict are magnified among participants with high identity centrality.  

Centrality scale (Sellers, Rowley, Chavou, Shelton, et al, 1997)
○	Overall, my race has very little to do with how I feel about myself, (reverse scored) 
○	In general, my race is an important part of my self-image. 
○	My destiny is tied to the destiny of other people from my race.
○	My race is unimportant to my sense of what kind of person I am. (reverse scored)
○	I have a strong sense of belonging to my race. 
○	I have a strong attachment to other people that are my race.
○	My race is an important reflection of who I am.
○	My race is not a major factor in my social relationships, (reverse scored)

We expect that the effect will be magnified among people who see a high degree of linked fate between Black individuals and the minority group members represented in their condition. 

Linked Fate (Ho, Kteily, and Chen, 2017) 
○	Blacks and Latino/Asians share a common destiny
○	Issues that affect the Black community also affect Latino/Asians
○	What happens to Latino/Asians does not have anything to do with what will happen to Blacks (reverse-scored)
○	Racial progress for Black people also means racial progress for Latino/Asians
○	When the way Blacks are treated in the U.S. changes, the way that Latino/Asians are treated will naturally follow.

Other variables:

Our first measures will be filler questions about the image presented in the stimulus materials (see details below under “Conditions”). 

Image accuracy: participants will be asked to identify the picture that they saw in the company flyer. They will have to choose from three different images.

Prompt: Given the picture above, please rate this picture with the following questions:
How appropriate is this image for this flyer? 
How reasonable is this picture for this flyer?
Do you think we have selected a good set of employees for this flyer?

Demographics: Age, gender, race, sexual orientation, trans status, us born, education

Conditions: How many and which conditions will participants be assigned to?

There will be two conditions in the current study: 1) Latino-White group, and 2) Asian-White group.

In the first condition, participants will see a recruiting flyer for a company. The flyer will contain a picture of four managers, two who are Latino and two who are White. The flyer will have generic information about the organization, such as its mission statement, business practices, and other basic organizational information. In the second condition, participants will see the same flyer but with two Asian managers in place of the two Latino managers. 

Analyses: Specify exactly which analyses you will conduct to examine the main question/hypothesis.

We will run a series of t-tests on our dependent and mediator variables. Our focal comparison is between our two conditions: the Latino-White condition and the Asian-White condition. 

We will also run mediation analyses using Hayes’ (2009) PROCESS models. In these analyses we will check to see if there is an indirect effect of condition on our two focal dependent variables (solidarity and oneness) through any of our potential mediators (specified above under “measures”). 

We will also examine whether identity centrality and / or our generalized measure of linked fate moderates any indirect effects we uncover. We will use PROCESS to conduct this analysis.

Finally, depending on the results we find through the analyses above, we may conduct exploratory analyses in which we examine solidarity and oneness as mediators of an effect on our other measures (i.e., we will explore a possible reversal of what we have theorized as our dependent and mediator variables). 

Outliers and Exclusions: Describe exactly how outliers will be defined and handled, and your precise rule(s) for excluding observations.

Upon starting the study, we will ask participants a detailed attention check to ensure they are paying attention to the study: 

People eat and drink throughout the day. We want to learn about how many times a day you eat and drink. This page is to see if you are reading the instructions carefully. For the questions that follow this paragraph, please just ignore the text of the questions, and type the word none as your answer. Thank you.

On average, how many times a day do you EAT SOMETHING? Please give your best estimate: [text entry]
On average, how many times a day do you DRINK SOMETHING? Please give your best estimate: [text entry]

We will also add an attention check in one of our scales and ask participants to select “somewhat agree” as their answer for that item.

We will exclude observations if the participants fail our attention checks. 

We will exclude individuals who fail our manipulation check. 

Sample Size: How many observations will be collected or what will determine sample size?

We plan to collect approximately 400 observations. To account for manipulation and attention check failures, we will recruit 460 with the aim of having 400 participants after exclusions.

If, upon removing participants who fail the attention checks and manipulation check, the sample is below 400, we will collect more data before conducting our analyses (until such a point at which the n is at least 400).

attributes.title: Stability in sequences of inharmonic sounds

q1.value: Perceived stability in sequences of inharmonic sounds

q3.value:
Given a musical scale, certain pitch classes and chords are typically perceived as more stable than others. For example, in the familiar white-note diatonic scale, the pitch class C and the C major chord are generally perceived as stable while the pitch class B and the G major chord are perceived as unstable (Milne et al. 2015).

Recent research has indicated that these feelings of stability and instability may be mediated by spectral pitch similarity (Milne et al. 2015). For example, with respect to the white-note diatonic scale, the unstable pitch class B has lower spectral pitch class similarity than does the stable pitch class C; the unstable chord G major has lower spectral pitch class similarity than does the stable chord C major. It was further hypothesised that a sequence of chords where there is low spectral similarity between the first and second chord, but high spectral similarity between the first and third and between the second and third enhances the perceived stability of that third chord (Milne 2010, Milne et al. 2015).

This experiment investigates whether these effects generalize to sequences of unfamiliar sounding inharmonic spectra. (Inharmonic spectra give a sensation of vague, ambiguous, or multiple pitches.) A positive result would support the proposition that tonality – hierarchies of stability – in Western music has psychoacoustic influences or origins.

The experiment comprises an exposure phase where participants learn to associate five different sounds with colours. They hear the sounds played in random order and consistently associated with a colour. They then hear each sound without any colour showing and are asked to indicate the matching colour. This is repeated twice. After this exposure phase, they then listen to 30 different three-sound sequences (each sound from the exposure set). They rate the "stability" of the final sound. This process is repeated twice so that each participant is exposed to, and tested on, three sets of five sounds. The sounds in each set are chosen to ensure that the sequences tested have a variety of spectral pitch similarity levels between the three sound pairs in each sequence.

q4.value:
H1: the perceived stability of a sound is positively associated with its spectral pitch similarity to its immediate context which, here, is the two sounds that precede it.

H2: the perceived stability of a sound is positively associated with its spectral pitch similarity to its broader context which, here, is the set of five sounds the participant was previously exposed to.

H3. the stability of a sound is positively associated with the spectral similarities between each pair of sounds in the sequence. In particular, sequences where the spectral pitch similarity between sounds 1 and 2 is less than that between sounds 1 and 3, and also less than that between sounds 2 and 3, are positively associated with perceived stability.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: With the exception of GMSI, all of predictors of interest vary within subject even though the stimuli themselves are, in part, between subject ("in part" due to the rolling design described below). The colour-sound association task is within subject and repeated within participant. For the ratings, some patterns of subsets of the predictors are repeated within participant, although no pattern of the full set of predictors is repeated within participant. Participants are allocated to three out of the 12 different sets of five different sounds, with a rolling design between the 12 sets. For example, participant 1 receives sets 1, 2, and 3, consecutively; participant 2 receives sets 2, 3, and 4, consecutively; and so forth. In the exposure test, sounds are matched with colours. There will be two different sound-colour combinations that are counterbalanced between participants, leading to a total of 24 different conditions overall.

q9.value:
Conditions are predetermined via a rolling design as described above and not randomised. Trials within those conditions are randomised. 

The stimuli were randomly generated under constraints specified for all sounds:
 - the number of partials in every sound in each set (8 or 12)
 - their amplitudes (all equal)
 - their rectangular distribution in log-frequency
 - ensuring a minimum frequency distance between partials to minimize beating
 - producing sets of five sounds, such that pairs of sounds in each set range widely in their spectral pitch similarities; in particular, with two exceptions, every sound is spectrally similar to two other sounds; there is at least one pair of sounds with extremely low spectral pitch similarity.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
60 first year psychology students will be recruited using Western Sydney University's online recruitment system. The only exclusion criterion is that they must not have abnormal hearing. Students will be reimbursed with 6 course credits.

Up to 24 musicians will be recruited, although achieving this number may be difficult and recruitment will cease when repeated efforts seem unlikely to bring in more than a few new participants. Musicians will be reimbursed with 30AUD.

q13.value: 60 student participants. A few more may end up being tested because sessions are overbooked to account for students not turning up. Up to 24 musician participants. Each participant will give a total of 90 ratings of stability and answer 45 tests of colour associations.

q14.value: These numbers have proved sufficient in previous related experiments. The analysis will be Bayesian, hence a power analysis is not appropriate.

q15.value: We will continue until 60 student participants have been tested. For musicians, we will aim to get 24 but, realistically, 18 is more likely. In the end, we will make a judgement call as to when the effort to obtain more musician participants exceeds the benefit they bring.

question.value: The fundamental manipulations here are the sounds chosen, and the sequences in which they are presented to the listener for the stability ratings.

The three pairwise spectral pitch similarities of each rated three-sound sequence (denoted spec_sim(sound1, sound2) for the similarity between the first sound in the sequence and the second sound in the sequence; spec_sim(sound1, sound3) for the similarity between the first sound in the sequence and the third sound in the sequence; spec_sim(sound2, sound3) for the similarity between the second sound in the sequence and the third sound in the sequence).

Spectral pitch similarity between sound3 and the full set of 5 sounds used in that part of the experiment (denoted spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set)). Also the spectral pitch similarity between the first and second sounds sound3 and the full set of 5 sounds used in that part of the experiment (denoted spec_sim(sound1,  sound_set) and spec_sim(sound2,  sound_set), respectively).

Roughness of each sound (denoted roughness1 for the first sound in the sequence, roughness2 for the second, roughness3 for the third)

Harmonicity of each sound (denoted harmonicity1, harmonicity2, harmonicity3, as above)

Mean pitch (centroid in log-frequency, denoted mean_pitch1, mean_pitch2, mean_pitch3)

Mean frequency  (centroid in frequency, denoted mean_freq1, mean_freq2, mean_freq3)

Participants' stability ratings (denoted stability)

Participants' colour matches to sounds (obtained in the exposure phase, denote accuracy)

Participants' musical sophistication (obtained with the Gold-MSI survey, denoted GMSI)

Participants' demographic and musical backgrounds (obtained by questions about ancestry, language spoken at home, music listened to, etc.)
The Gold-MSI has a combined score, which summarises all aspects of musicianship it covers.

Bayesian ordinal regression model, specified below with the familiar R syntax for mixed-effects model formulae:

stability ~ 1 + (spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound2) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound1) + 
                        spec_sim(sound2, sound1) + 
                        mean_pitch3 + 
                        roughness3 +
                        harmonicity3)  * 
                        (GMSI + accuracy) +
                (1 + (spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound2) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound1) + 
                        spec_sim(sound2, sound1) +
                        mean_pitch3 +
                        roughness3 +
                        harmonicity3) * 
                        accuracy | participant) + 
                (1 + (spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound2) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound1) + 
                        spec_sim(sound2, sound1)) *
                        (GMSI + accuracy) | sound3) 

The predictors are defined in "Measured variables". Either mean_pitch3 or mean_freq3 will be used after testing which performs better under cross-validation. 

If feasible to fit, mean_pitch1, roughness1, harmonicity1, mean_pitch2, roughness2, harmonicity2, spec_sim(sound1,  sound_set), and spec_sim(sound2,  sound_set) will also be included as additive predictors.

If models do not converge or, if supported by cross-validation, random effects will be removed. For example, there may be insufficient variation to useful include random effects grouped by sound3, and it may not be feasible to include accuracy as a random effect grouped by participant.

For predictors' effects, weakly informative priors will be used -- e.g., for standardized predictors, student-t(3,0,1)

q20.value: Predictors may be standardized if this aids interpretation. Note that, due to the inference methods outlined in "Inference criteria", standardizing (or not) will have no impact on the inferences made.

q21.value:
Inferences will made using the posterior distributions of the predictors' effects. These will be characterized by their evidence ratios (odds of their probability of direction) with >10 indicating strong evidence, >30 very strong evidence. 

For model comparisons, PSIS-LOO will be used, with an ELPD difference greater than 2 times its standard error indicating sufficient evidence for that difference.

q22.value: Data will be excluded only if it is clear the task has been misunderstood by the participant, they were acting in a deliberately contrary manner, or there was some error in the data collection.

q23.value: Given the experimental nature of this study, we do not anticipate missing data.

q24.value: We may explore how demographic traits and prior musical exposure influence ratings.

registration_responses.q14: These numbers have proved sufficient in previous related experiments. The analysis will be Bayesian, hence a power analysis is not appropriate.
registration_responses.q15: We will continue until 60 student participants have been tested. For musicians, we will aim to get 24 but, realistically, 18 is more likely. In the end, we will make a judgement call as to when the effort to obtain more musician participants exceeds the benefit they bring.
registration_responses.q20: Predictors may be standardized if this aids interpretation. Note that, due to the inference methods outlined in "Inference criteria", standardizing (or not) will have no impact on the inferences made.
registration_responses.q21:
Inferences will made using the posterior distributions of the predictors' effects. These will be characterized by their evidence ratios (odds of their probability of direction) with >10 indicating strong evidence, >30 very strong evidence. 

For model comparisons, PSIS-LOO will be used, with an ELPD difference greater than 2 times its standard error indicating sufficient evidence for that difference.
registration_responses.q22: Data will be excluded only if it is clear the task has been misunderstood by the participant, they were acting in a deliberately contrary manner, or there was some error in the data collection.
registration_responses.q23: Given the experimental nature of this study, we do not anticipate missing data.
registration_responses.q24: We may explore how demographic traits and prior musical exposure influence ratings.
registration_responses.q8.question: With the exception of GMSI, all of predictors of interest vary within subject even though the stimuli themselves are, in part, between subject ("in part" due to the rolling design described below). The colour-sound association task is within subject and repeated within participant. For the ratings, some patterns of subsets of the predictors are repeated within participant, although no pattern of the full set of predictors is repeated within participant. Participants are allocated to three out of the 12 different sets of five different sounds, with a rolling design between the 12 sets. For example, participant 1 receives sets 1, 2, and 3, consecutively; participant 2 receives sets 2, 3, and 4, consecutively; and so forth. In the exposure test, sounds are matched with colours. There will be two different sound-colour combinations that are counterbalanced between participants, leading to a total of 24 different conditions overall.
registration_responses.q12.question:
60 first year psychology students will be recruited using Western Sydney University's online recruitment system. The only exclusion criterion is that they must not have abnormal hearing. Students will be reimbursed with 6 course credits.

Up to 24 musicians will be recruited, although achieving this number may be difficult and recruitment will cease when repeated efforts seem unlikely to bring in more than a few new participants. Musicians will be reimbursed with 30AUD.
registration_responses.q16.question: The fundamental manipulations here are the sounds chosen, and the sequences in which they are presented to the listener for the stability ratings.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The three pairwise spectral pitch similarities of each rated three-sound sequence (denoted spec_sim(sound1, sound2) for the similarity between the first sound in the sequence and the second sound in the sequence; spec_sim(sound1, sound3) for the similarity between the first sound in the sequence and the third sound in the sequence; spec_sim(sound2, sound3) for the similarity between the second sound in the sequence and the third sound in the sequence).

Spectral pitch similarity between sound3 and the full set of 5 sounds used in that part of the experiment (denoted spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set)). Also the spectral pitch similarity between the first and second sounds sound3 and the full set of 5 sounds used in that part of the experiment (denoted spec_sim(sound1,  sound_set) and spec_sim(sound2,  sound_set), respectively).

Roughness of each sound (denoted roughness1 for the first sound in the sequence, roughness2 for the second, roughness3 for the third)

Harmonicity of each sound (denoted harmonicity1, harmonicity2, harmonicity3, as above)

Mean pitch (centroid in log-frequency, denoted mean_pitch1, mean_pitch2, mean_pitch3)

Mean frequency  (centroid in frequency, denoted mean_freq1, mean_freq2, mean_freq3)

Participants' stability ratings (denoted stability)

Participants' colour matches to sounds (obtained in the exposure phase, denote accuracy)

Participants' musical sophistication (obtained with the Gold-MSI survey, denoted GMSI)

Participants' demographic and musical backgrounds (obtained by questions about ancestry, language spoken at home, music listened to, etc.)
registration_responses.q18.question: The Gold-MSI has a combined score, which summarises all aspects of musicianship it covers.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Bayesian ordinal regression model, specified below with the familiar R syntax for mixed-effects model formulae:

stability ~ 1 + (spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound2) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound1) + 
                        spec_sim(sound2, sound1) + 
                        mean_pitch3 + 
                        roughness3 +
                        harmonicity3)  * 
                        (GMSI + accuracy) +
                (1 + (spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound2) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound1) + 
                        spec_sim(sound2, sound1) +
                        mean_pitch3 +
                        roughness3 +
                        harmonicity3) * 
                        accuracy | participant) + 
                (1 + (spec_sim(sound3,  sound_set) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound2) + 
                        spec_sim(sound3, sound1) + 
                        spec_sim(sound2, sound1)) *
                        (GMSI + accuracy) | sound3) 

The predictors are defined in "Measured variables". Either mean_pitch3 or mean_freq3 will be used after testing which performs better under cross-validation. 

If feasible to fit, mean_pitch1, roughness1, harmonicity1, mean_pitch2, roughness2, harmonicity2, spec_sim(sound1,  sound_set), and spec_sim(sound2,  sound_set) will also be included as additive predictors.

If models do not converge or, if supported by cross-validation, random effects will be removed. For example, there may be insufficient variation to useful include random effects grouped by sound3, and it may not be feasible to include accuracy as a random effect grouped by participant.

For predictors' effects, weakly informative priors will be used -- e.g., for standardized predictors, student-t(3,0,1)

attributes.title: Psychometric properties of the validated scales to assess activity and participation of people with muscular dystrophies in the ICF context: a systematic review

q1.value: Psychometric properties of the validated scales to assess activity and participation of people with muscular dystrophies in the ICF context: a systematic review

q3.value: Muscular dystrophies are an inherited group of neuromuscular disease that leads to progressive muscle wasting and strength loss. The rehabilitation process based on the  International Classification of functioning disability and health (ICF) model uses functional outcome measurements to follow the progression of the disease and the results of specific interventions centered on the patient's expectation and needs. This study aims to identify scales that present psychometric properties of measurement to muscular dystrophies allocating them according to tho the quality of these properties and the ICF domains.

q4.value: There are some scales to muscular dystrophies that have psychometric properties and approach ICF domains.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The registration study is a systematic review of the literature about the methodological quality of the psychometric properties of the validated scales to muscular dystrophies. This review will be structured according to the PRISMA and the protocol will be registered at PROSPERO and OSF.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
This systematic review will be conducted by searching the following electronic databases: MEDLINE, LILACS, DITAS, SCIELO, PHYSCHINFO, PUBMED. Bibliographical and key author searches from the included studies will be used to expand the search for other appropriate articles. 
Articles of any design who had investigated the measurement properties of scales to muscular dystrophy population of any age (children and adult); studies who investigate one or more psychometric properties of activity and/or participation scales according to COSMIN taxonomy. 
Exclusion: expert opinion, case reports, only abstract available.
There will be no limit to language or date of publication.

q13.value: Once the study is a systematic review we will include all articles that match the inclusion criteria and exclude the ones that do not follow these criteria. A flowchart will be outlined to detail the number of articles included in the analysis.

question.value: Not applicable to the study.

The number of articles that fit the following criteria: 1.muscular dystrophy population of any age (children and adult) and 2. studies who investigate one or more psychometric properties of activity and/or participation scales according to COSMIN taxonomy

Two independent reviewers will work on the data extraction that will assess if articles fit the inclusion and exclusion criteria. When considered eligible, articles will be included in this study. A third reviewer will be consulted if there is no consensus. 
A narrative synthesis will be carried out where the quality of the psychometric property of the scales and its relation to ICF domains of activity and participation will be described. After, the authors will conduct a descriptive synthesis of the assessed ICF domains of the scales with the best measurement qualities.

attributes.title: Testing the robustness of the foreign-language truth effect
attributes.description: Experiment 2: The experiment investigates whether foreign language moderates the repetition-based truth effect and explores the underlying mechanisms of this foreign-language effect.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Testing the robustness of the foreign-language truth effect: Experiment 2

other.value:
Secondary analysis: Effects of source attributions on truth judgments will be explored by mean of a 2 (recognition judgment: yes vs. no) x 2 (external attribution: yes vs. no) x 2 (language: native vs. foreign) repeated measures ANOVA. If there are too many missing values for a cell of the design, we consider to integrate the two factors recognition and external attribution into the factor source attribution (external source, experiment only, statement not seen before). Truth judgments for statements attributed to external sources should be highest whereas truth judgments for statements judged to be new should be lowest (Arkes, Hackett, & Boehm, 1989; Nadarevic and Aßfalg, 2017). There is no reason to assume that language moderates this effect.

Variables for exploratory purposes: If participants indicate that they had used external help or a dictionary, it will be checked if excluding these participants will alter the main results.

sample.value: A minimum sample size of N = 80 will be collected. This minimum sample size is based on a power analysis with G-Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) with the following parameters:  α =.05, 1-β = .80, ρ = .15 (estimated correlation among repeated measures), and f = .15 (effect-size estimate) for the hypothesized interaction effect of the repeated measure factors repetition (repeated vs. new) and language (native vs. foreign). Because G*Power does not involve an F-test module for tests of within-within interactions, the power calculations were computed by means of the “Generic F-Test” module. Using the feature “post-hoc power analysis” N was increased iteratively (resulting in different lambda and df values) until the desired power criterion (1-β = .80) was reached.

analyses.value:
H1: Mean truth judgments will be analyzed with a 2 (repetition: repeated vs. new) x 2 (truth status: true vs. false) x 2 (language: native vs. foreign) within-subjects ANOVA. The expected effects are: A main effect of repetition based on higher truth judgments for repeated compared to new statements (i.e. the truth effect). An interaction between repetition and language due to a larger truth effect in the native compared to the foreign language condition. 

H2: Recognition memory performance (p(hits) - p(false alarms) is expected to be higher for native than for foreign language statements. This will be tested with a one-sided t-test for dependent variables. 

H3: The proportion of statements assigned to an external source will be analyzed with a 2 (repetition: repeated vs. new) x 2 (language: native vs. foreign) within-subject ANOVA (for a similar analysis of source dissociations, see Nadarevic & Aßfalg, 2017, Experiment 1). The expected effects are: A main effect of repetition (i.e. more external source attributions for repeated than for new statements) and a repetition by language interaction. It is expected that the effect of repetition on external source attributions is stronger for native-langauge statements than for foreign-language statements.

H4: Three linear regression analyses will be conducted:
- A regression analysis with mean truth judgments for the foreign-language statements as the criterion and repetition (yes vs. no), truth status (true vs. false), and the LexTale score (continious) as the predictors. An effect of repetition as well as an interaction between repetition and language proficiency as measured by the LexTale score are expected.
- A regression analysis with recognition memory performance (p(hits) - p(false alarms) for the foreign-language statements as the criterion and the LexTale score (continious) as the predictor. A positive relationship between LexTale score and recognition memory is expected.
- A regression analysis with the proportion of external source attributions for the foreign-language statements as the criterion and statement repetition (repeated vs. new) and LexTale score (continious) as the predictors. An effect of repetition as well as an interaction between repetition and language proficiency as measured by the LexTale score are expected.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded if one of the following criteria applies:
- their native language is not German
- they indicate that they did not participate seriously
- they judge more than one out of four easy control statements incorrectly (incorrect is defined as a truth rating of 3 to 6 for false statements and a truth rating of 1 to 4 for true statements, respectively).

dependent.value:
Truth ratings serve as the dependent variable to test H1. Truth ratings will be measured on a six-point rating scale ranging from “definitely false” (1) to “definitely true” (6). 

Recognition memory will be assessed by the following question: “Have you already seen the statement in the first session of the study?”. The proportion of hits (p(hits)) minus the proportion of false alarms (p(false alarms)) serves as the dependent variable to test H2.

Source dissociations will be assessed by the following question: “Have you ever seen or heard the statement outside the study?” The proportion of statements assigned to an external source serves as the dependent variable to test H3.

In order to test H4, foreign-language proficiency will be measured by the LexTALE (Lemhöfer & Broersma, 2012).

conditions.value: Participants judge the truth of 56 statements (28 true and 28 false ones) in session 2 of the experiment. Half of these statements are repeated statements from session 1 (taking place two weeks earlier). The other statements are new. Within each truth status and repetition condition, half of the statements are presented in German (native language) and the other half in English (foreign language). Hence, the design is a complete within-subject design with the independent variables repetition (repeated vs. new), truth status (true vs. false), and language (native vs. foreign). The assignment of statements to the factors repetition and language is counterbalanced between participants.

hypothesis.value:
The goal of this experiment is to test whether foreign language moderates the repetition-based truth effect. Nadarevic, Plier, Thielmann, and Darancó (2018, Experiment 2) found a smaller truth effect for foreign language statements than for native language statements when there was a two-week retention interval between initial and repeated statement presentation. The current experiment aims to test the robustness of this finding by manipulating language (native: German, foreign: English) in a within-subjects instead of between-subjects design. In addition, the experiment aims to explore the underlying cognitive mechanisms of the expected foreign-language truth effect. The hypotheses are:

Hypothesis 1 (H1): After a two-week interval, the truth effect will be smaller for foreign-language statements than for native language statements (conceptual replication of Nadarevic et al., 2018, Experiment 2)

Hypothesis 2 (H2): Participants will show better recognition memory for the native language statements than for foreign language statements. This hypothesis is based on the idea that the familiarity of foreign-language statements decreases faster within the two-week interval than the familiarity of native-language statements (Nadarevic et al., 2018).

Hypothesis 3 (H3): According on the source dissociation hypothesis (Arkes, Boehm, & Xu, 1991) people tend to misattribute repeated statements to sources outside of the experiment. It is expected that such source dissociations will appear more often for native language statements than for foreign language statements.

Hypothesis 4 (H4): Foreign-language proficiency moderates the following effects for foreign language statements. The better the foreign-language proficiency, a) the larger the truth effect for foreign-language statements, b) the better the recognition memory for foreign language statements, and c) the higher the proportion of source dissociations for foreign-language statements.

conditions.value: Participants judge the truth of 48 statements (24 true and 24 false ones) in session 2 of the experiment. Half of these statements are repeated statements from session 1 (taking place two weeks earlier). The other statements are new ones. Within each truth status and repetition condition, half of the statements are presented in German (native language) and the other half in Spanish (foreign language). Hence, the design is a complete within-subject design with the independent variables repetition (repeated vs. new), truth status (true vs. false), and language (native vs. foreign). The assignment of statements to the factors repetition and language is counterbalanced between participants.

hypothesis.value:
The goal of this experiment is to test whether foreign language moderates the repetition-based truth effect. Nadarevic, Plier, Thielmann, and Darancó (2018, Experiment 2) found a smaller truth effect for foreign language statements than for native language statements when there was a two-week retention interval between initial and repeated statement presentation. The current experiment aims to test the robustness of this finding by manipulating language (native vs. foreign) in a within-subjects instead of between-subjects design and by using Spanish instead of English as the foreign language. As in the original study, the native language will be German. The hypotheses are:

Hypothesis 1 (H1): After a two-week interval, the truth effect will be smaller for foreign-language statements than for native language statements (conceptual replication of Nadarevic et al., 2018, Experiment 2)

Hypothesis 2 (H2): Foreign-language proficiency moderates the truth effect for foreign language statements. The better the foreign-language proficiency, the larger the truth effect for foreign-language statements.

registration_responses.other: If participants indicate that they had used external help or a dictionary, it will be checked if excluding these participants will alter the results.
registration_responses.sample: A sample size of at least N = 80 will be collected. This minimum sample size is based on a power analysis with G-Power 3.1 (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) with the following parameters:  α =.05, 1-β = .80, ρ = .15 (estimated correlation among repeated measures), and f = .15 (effect-size estimate) for the hypothesized interaction effect of the repeated measure factors repetition (repeated vs. new) and language (native vs. foreign). Because G*Power does not involve an F-test module for tests of within-within interactions, the power calculations were computed by means of the “Generic F-Test” module. Using the feature “post-hoc power analysis” N was increased iteratively (resulting in different lambda and df values) until the desired power criterion (1-β = .80) was reached.
registration_responses.analyses:
Test of H1: Mean truth judgments will be analyzed with a 2 (repetition: repeated vs. new) x 2 (truth status: true vs. false) x 2 (language: native vs. foreign) within-subjects ANOVA. The expected effects are: A main effect of repetition based on higher truth judgments for repeated compared to new statements (i.e. the truth effect). An interaction between repetition and language due to a larger truth effect in the native compared to the foreign language condition. 

Test of H2: A linear regression analysis with mean truth judgments for the foreign-language statements as the criterion and repetition (yes vs. no), truth status (true vs. false), and the Lextale-Esp score (continious) as the predictors will be conducted. An effect of repetition as well as an interaction between repetition and language proficiency as measured by the Lextale-Esp score are expected.
registration_responses.outliers:
Participants will be excluded if one of the following criteria apply:
- their native language is not German
- they indicate that they did not participate seriously
- they judge more than one out of four easy control statements incorrectly (incorrect judgments are defined as a truth rating of 3 to 6 for false statements and a truth rating of 1 to 4 for true statements, respectively).
registration_responses.dependent:
Truth ratings serve as the dependent variable to test H1. Truth ratings will be measured on a six-point scale ranging from “definitely false” (1) to “definitely true” (6). 

In order to test H2, foreign-language proficiency will be measured by the Lextale-Esp (Izura, Cuetos, & Brysbaert, 2014).
registration_responses.conditions: Participants judge the truth of 48 statements (24 true and 24 false ones) in session 2 of the experiment. Half of these statements are repeated statements from session 1 (taking place two weeks earlier). The other statements are new ones. Within each truth status and repetition condition, half of the statements are presented in German (native language) and the other half in Spanish (foreign language). Hence, the design is a complete within-subject design with the independent variables repetition (repeated vs. new), truth status (true vs. false), and language (native vs. foreign). The assignment of statements to the factors repetition and language is counterbalanced between participants.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The goal of this experiment is to test whether foreign language moderates the repetition-based truth effect. Nadarevic, Plier, Thielmann, and Darancó (2018, Experiment 2) found a smaller truth effect for foreign language statements than for native language statements when there was a two-week retention interval between initial and repeated statement presentation. The current experiment aims to test the robustness of this finding by manipulating language (native vs. foreign) in a within-subjects instead of between-subjects design and by using Spanish instead of English as the foreign language. As in the original study, the native language will be German. The hypotheses are:

Hypothesis 1 (H1): After a two-week interval, the truth effect will be smaller for foreign-language statements than for native language statements (conceptual replication of Nadarevic et al., 2018, Experiment 2)

Hypothesis 2 (H2): Foreign-language proficiency moderates the truth effect for foreign language statements. The better the foreign-language proficiency, the larger the truth effect for foreign-language statements.

attributes.title: Design Principles of youth development programs in outdoor environments: A scoping review
attributes.description: Despite increased popular and research interest in youth development and outdoor education, very little research has focused upon the design principles that maximise the effectiveness of these programs. This scoping review will review the literature discussing youth development activities occurring in outdoor environments, in order to identify the design principles of effective activities.

summary.value: Despite increased popular and research interest in youth development and outdoor education, very little research has focused upon the design principles that maximise the effectiveness of these programs. Employing this registered protocol, this scoping review will review the literature discussing youth development activities occurring in outdoor environments, in order to identify the design principles of effective activities.

registration_responses.summary: Despite increased popular and research interest in youth development and outdoor education, very little research has focused upon the design principles that maximise the effectiveness of these programs. q15.value: TurkPrime occasionally includes a few extra participants. Therefore, our stopping rule will be to stop when TurkPrime states that the study has been completed.

question.value: We will manipulate parenting motivation through a slideshow. Half the participants will receive this slideshow, while the other half will receive a control slideshow where they think about their everyday life.

We will measure the following: 
1) Desire for the dependent variable product - phone choice between a functional phone and an aesthetic (less functional) phone
2) Feelings that their own social image impacts the social image of a child
3) Concern for impression management
4) Manipulation check of video (i.e., Feelings of being a parent and parental emotions)
5) Perception that the aesthetic product is seen as enhancing image to nearby observes when in public environments.

Feelings of being a parent (4 items; manipulation check) will be averaged into one variable as well.  The 3 emotion items (nurturing, loving, devoted; again, part of the manipulation check) will be combined into one variable via creating a mean. Additionally, the measures for the impression management concerns (3 items; distal mediator) will be combined into one item via creating a mean.
We will use an ANOVA to test the main effect. We will also use Hayes Process Macro to test the mediation model and the overall effect. 5000 bootstraps will be used.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The Hayes Process Analysis will use confidence intervals to test the efficacy of the mediation.

q22.value: No participants will be excluded unless they skip the dependent variable.

q23.value: We will use participants' data except for the missing items, which will be left missing.

attributes.title: Frontal Gamma Power in Infancy: Relations with socioeconomic status and language outcomes

q1.value: Frontal Gamma Power in Infancy: Relations with socioeconomic status and language outcomes

q3.value:
This study will be investigating relations between socio-economic status (SES)/early adversity, resting frontal gamma power in infancy/toddlerhood, and later language outcomes. Recent work has reported that power in the gamma frequency range (25-45 Hz) is associated with both SES and later language outcomes (Benasich et al., 2008; Brito et al., 2016; Gabard-Durnam et al., 2017). Specifically, lower socioeconomic status has been associated with reduced gamma power (Cantiani, Piazza, Mornati, Molteni, & Riva, 2019), specifically frontal gamma power (Tomalski et al., 2013). On the other hand, higher frontal gamma power in infancy/toddlerhood is associated with better language outcomes in early childhood (Gou, Choudhury, & Benasich, 2011) and no history of familial language impairment (Benasich, Gou, Choudhury, & Harris, 2008). Thus, there is a rising interest in early experience’s impact on frontal gamma power and subsequent language development.
However, resting gamma power is typically only a small portion of the total EEG power spectrum and has been shown to at least partially be contaminated by oculo-motor artifacts (Hipp & Siegel, 2013), a particularly difficult problem in young infants. Thus, we are interested in testing the conceptual replicability of relations between frontal gamma power and SES/language across three independent datasets by: 1) examining the presence of gamma in infants as well as 2) its relations to early adverse environmental characteristics and later language outcomes. Moreover, we will test the specificity of these relations to gamma as opposed to other frequency bands or overall shifts in the entire power spectrum.

q4.value: Our hypothesis is that we will be unable to find relations between frontal gamma power in infancy and socioeconomic status in three independent datasets. Further, we will not replicate relations between frontal gamma power in infancy and later language outcomes in toddlerhood.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Correlational analyses exploring correlations between infant frontal gamma power and SES and between infant frontal gamma power and later language outcomes.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Thus far, we have not explored any summary statistics for our samples in our variables of interest. The registrant is the only person to have access to the data and did not open SPSS files with the data prior to this pre-registration.
EEG data were pre-processed (e.g., filtered and artifact rejection), but no quantifiable measures have been explored (e.g., power in any frequency band).

question.value: Data was already collected and we are pre-registering prior to analysis

q13.value:
Data have already been collected, yet the proposed analyses have not yet taken place.  We will use available data from three existing longitudinal datasets. 
	1. The first dataset is the Temperament over Time Study (TOTS) from Dr. Nathan Fox’s
lab at the University of Maryland. The TOTS dataset consists of 291 participants who were screened at 4months of age, then selected to continue in the study based on 	temperament profiles. The EEG was collected as age 9 months in a subset of participants (n = 223).
	2. The second dataset is the Bucharest Early Intervention Project (BEIP), headed by Dr. Nathan Fox, Dr. Charles Zeanah, and Dr. Charles Nelson. BEIP includes 208 participants: 68 in an institutionalized group, 68 in a foster care group, and 72 in a never institutionalized group all from Bucharest, Romania. Here, the EEG was collected 	between 6 – 31 months at baseline.
	3. The third dataset is from the study of cognition and emotion from infancy through adolescence from Dr. Martha Ann Bell’s lab at Virginia Tech University. This sample includes about 200 participants at age 10 months.

q14.value: We are restricted to using participants that have already been collected.

question.value: N/A - observational study

The dependent variables of interest are gamma power (25 – 45Hz), SES/early adversity, and language development. 
Gamma power:
Frontal gamma power will be derived from EEG recordings taken in infancy/toddlerhood in the three independent datasets. All recordings will be processed in the same way. First, data from 10 electrodes will be filtered with a 0.5Hz highpass filter and 50Hz lowpass hamming FIR filter. Resting state data will be epoched into 1 second epochs and baseline corrected over the entire epoch. Any epoch with a channel greater than +/-200mv activity was rejected. The data will then be re-referenced to the average of the electrodes. Frontal gamma power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 25-45Hz range at electrodes F3 and F4 during resting state in infants. The 25-45Hz range was determined based on previous work examining gamma in infants/toddlerhood (Brito et al., 2017; Gabard-Durnam et al., 2019).

SES/adversity:
The three independent datasets (described in section 5 below) being utilized in this study include different measures of SES/adversity. In two datasets, level of maternal education will be used as SES. In the third, percent time in an institution will be used as a measure of adversity.

Language:
Again, the three datasets in this study include various measures of language development. For two of the datasets, the MacArthur-Bates Communicative Development Inventory (MCDI) language composite at 24 months will be used as the language outcome. For the third dataset, the Receptive-Expressive Emergent Language Test (REEL) at age 30 months will be used. 

For secondary/exploratory analyses (described in section 4b), we will explore relations between SES/language and other frequency bands and power spectrum characteristics. Thus, we will also be using the following variables. Frequency bins are based on previous work investigating infant EEG power (Brito et al., 2017; Gabard-Durnam et al., 2019).
1) Delta power: Delta power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 1-3.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
2) Theta power: Theta power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 4-5.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
3) Low Alpha power: Low alpha power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 6-8.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
4) High Alpha power: High alpha power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 9-12.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
5) Beta power: Beta power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 13-24.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
6) The intercept of the power spectrum for each participant will be measured using the FOOOF toolbox. The intercept reflects a broadband offset of the aperiodic signal of the power spectrum. 
7) The slope of the power spectrum from 1-45 Hz will be assessed using the FOOOF toolbox. The slope represents the changes of the aperiodic signal over this range of frequencies.

Our main analytic plan will have three steps:
i. Step 1: Is there gamma power in infancy? We will quantify mean levels of gamma power over the scalp in infancy/toddlerhood at rest, specifically averaged over the right and left hemisphere over two frontal sites (F3, F4). We will test if frontal gamma power in infancy is significantly different from 0. We expect that frontal gamma power will be significantly different from 0. Even if it is not, there still may be meaningful individual differences in frontal gamma power (as explored in the subsequent analyses).
ii. Step 2: Examine relations between SES/early adversity and frontal gamma power in infancy/toddlerhood. 
Next, we will examine the relation between frontal gamma power and SES/adversity. Because the datasets included in this study (described in section 5 below), utilize different measures of SES/adversity, analyses will be conducted separately for each dataset. The first and third datasets will examine if there are any differences in frontal gamma power based on maternal education. In the second dataset, we will examine the relation between percent time in an institution (i.e., early adversity) and frontal gamma power. 

iii. Step 3: Examine relations between frontal gamma power and language outcomes.
Third, we will examine the relation between frontal gamma power and language development. Tests for significant correlations between frontal gamma power and the language scores for each dataset, will be conducted.

q20.value: Infants must have at least 20 seconds of clean data to be included in the EEG analyses.

q21.value: We will be utilizing p values < 0.05 for all analyses.

q22.value: With our particular interest in individual differences, outliers may be meaningful, so we will run all analyses with and without outliers +/-3 SD from the mean.

q24.value:
1) Are the relations between SES and gamma power specific to frontal gamma? Are there also relations between SES and other frequency bands? Or between SES and gamma at other topographic sites?
Our main analyses focus on frontal gamma power in an effort to maximize chances of replication based on previous work, but we also wanted to more fully explore the specificity of the relation between SES and frontal gamma power. Thus, we will conduct an omnibus multi-level model predicting frequency power. The model for the first and third dataset will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma), and maternal education.
The model for the second dataset will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), and frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma). Percent time in the institution will be grand-mean centered and entered as a predictor. Finally, for the fourth dataset, the model will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), and frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma). The SES composite will be grand-mean centered and entered as a predictor.
2) Are the relations between language and gamma power specific to frontal gamma? Are there also relations between language and other frequency bands? Or between language and gamma at other sites?
To further explore the specificity of the relation between language and frontal gamma, we will conduct an omnibus multi-level model predicting frequency power. The model for the first, third, and fourth dataset will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma), and grand-mean centered MCDI scores. The model for the second dataset will be the same, but with grand-mean centered REEL scores.

3) Are the relations between frontal gamma power and SES or language explained by characteristics of the overall EEG power spectrum? Recent work has begun to characterize the entire power spectrum with meaningful measures of the intercept and slope of the 1/f distribution of the power spectrum. These measures have been associated with processing speed (Ouyang, Hildebrandt, Schmitz, & Herrmann, 2020). As such, we are interested in evaluating if these measures account for the associations between SES and gamma or between gamma and language. Thus, we will also complete one exploratory multiple regression predicting SES from frontal gamma power, intercept of the power spectrum, and slope of the power spectrum. We will also complete another exploratory multiple regression predicting language outcomes from frontal gamma power, intercept of the power spectrum, and slope of the power spectrum.
4) If no significant relations are found, we will use Bayesian statistics to determine if the data support the null hypothesis.

Thus, we are interested in testing the conceptual replicability of relations between frontal gamma power and SES/language across three independent datasets by: 1) examining the presence of gamma in infants as well as 2) its relations to early adverse environmental characteristics and later language outcomes. Moreover, we will test the specificity of these relations to gamma as opposed to other frequency bands or overall shifts in the entire power spectrum.
registration_responses.q4: Our hypothesis is that we will be unable to find relations between frontal gamma power in infancy and socioeconomic status in three independent datasets. Further, we will not replicate relations between frontal gamma power in infancy and later language outcomes in toddlerhood.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
Thus far, we have not explored any summary statistics for our samples in our variables of interest. The registrant is the only person to have access to the data and did not open SPSS files with the data prior to this pre-registration.
EEG data were pre-processed (e.g., filtered and artifact rejection), but no quantifiable measures have been explored (e.g., power in any frequency band).
registration_responses.q13:
Data have already been collected, yet the proposed analyses have not yet taken place.  We will use available data from three existing longitudinal datasets. 
	1. The first dataset is the Temperament over Time Study (TOTS) from Dr. Nathan Fox’s
lab at the University of Maryland. The TOTS dataset consists of 291 participants who were screened at 4months of age, then selected to continue in the study based on 	temperament profiles. The EEG was collected as age 9 months in a subset of participants (n = 223).
	2. The second dataset is the Bucharest Early Intervention Project (BEIP), headed by Dr. Nathan Fox, Dr. Charles Zeanah, and Dr. Charles Nelson. BEIP includes 208 participants: 68 in an institutionalized group, 68 in a foster care group, and 72 in a never institutionalized group all from Bucharest, Romania. Here, the EEG was collected 	between 6 – 31 months at baseline.
	3. The third dataset is from the study of cognition and emotion from infancy through adolescence from Dr. Martha Ann Bell’s lab at Virginia Tech University. This sample includes about 200 participants at age 10 months.
registration_responses.q14: We are restricted to using participants that have already been collected.
registration_responses.q20: Infants must have at least 20 seconds of clean data to be included in the EEG analyses.
registration_responses.q21: We will be utilizing p values < 0.05 for all analyses.
registration_responses.q22: With our particular interest in individual differences, outliers may be meaningful, so we will run all analyses with and without outliers +/-3 SD from the mean.
registration_responses.q24:
1) Are the relations between SES and gamma power specific to frontal gamma? Are there also relations between SES and other frequency bands? Or between SES and gamma at other topographic sites?
Our main analyses focus on frontal gamma power in an effort to maximize chances of replication based on previous work, but we also wanted to more fully explore the specificity of the relation between SES and frontal gamma power. Thus, we will conduct an omnibus multi-level model predicting frequency power. The model for the first and third dataset will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma), and maternal education.
The model for the second dataset will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), and frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma). Percent time in the institution will be grand-mean centered and entered as a predictor. Finally, for the fourth dataset, the model will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), and frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma). The SES composite will be grand-mean centered and entered as a predictor.
2) Are the relations between language and gamma power specific to frontal gamma? Are there also relations between language and other frequency bands? Or between language and gamma at other sites?
To further explore the specificity of the relation between language and frontal gamma, we will conduct an omnibus multi-level model predicting frequency power. The model for the first, third, and fourth dataset will include a fixed effect of caudality (frontal, central, parietal, occipital), hemisphere (right, left), frequency band (delta, theta, low alpha, high alpha, beta, and gamma), and grand-mean centered MCDI scores. The model for the second dataset will be the same, but with grand-mean centered REEL scores.

3) Are the relations between frontal gamma power and SES or language explained by characteristics of the overall EEG power spectrum? Recent work has begun to characterize the entire power spectrum with meaningful measures of the intercept and slope of the 1/f distribution of the power spectrum. These measures have been associated with processing speed (Ouyang, Hildebrandt, Schmitz, & Herrmann, 2020). As such, we are interested in evaluating if these measures account for the associations between SES and gamma or between gamma and language. Thus, we will also complete one exploratory multiple regression predicting SES from frontal gamma power, intercept of the power spectrum, and slope of the power spectrum. We will also complete another exploratory multiple regression predicting language outcomes from frontal gamma power, intercept of the power spectrum, and slope of the power spectrum.
4) If no significant relations are found, we will use Bayesian statistics to determine if the data support the null hypothesis.
registration_responses.q8.question: Correlational analyses exploring correlations between infant frontal gamma power and SES and between infant frontal gamma power and later language outcomes.

registration_responses.q17.question:
The dependent variables of interest are gamma power (25 – 45Hz), SES/early adversity, and language development. 
Gamma power:
Frontal gamma power will be derived from EEG recordings taken in infancy/toddlerhood in the three independent datasets. All recordings will be processed in the same way. First, data from 10 electrodes will be filtered with a 0.5Hz highpass filter and 50Hz lowpass hamming FIR filter. Resting state data will be epoched into 1 second epochs and baseline corrected over the entire epoch. Any epoch with a channel greater than +/-200mv activity was rejected. The data will then be re-referenced to the average of the electrodes. Frontal gamma power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 25-45Hz range at electrodes F3 and F4 during resting state in infants. The 25-45Hz range was determined based on previous work examining gamma in infants/toddlerhood (Brito et al., 2017; Gabard-Durnam et al., 2019).

SES/adversity:
The three independent datasets (described in section 5 below) being utilized in this study include different measures of SES/adversity. In two datasets, level of maternal education will be used as SES. In the third, percent time in an institution will be used as a measure of adversity.

Language:
Again, the three datasets in this study include various measures of language development. For two of the datasets, the MacArthur-Bates Communicative Development Inventory (MCDI) language composite at 24 months will be used as the language outcome. For the third dataset, the Receptive-Expressive Emergent Language Test (REEL) at age 30 months will be used. 

For secondary/exploratory analyses (described in section 4b), we will explore relations between SES/language and other frequency bands and power spectrum characteristics. Thus, we will also be using the following variables. Frequency bins are based on previous work investigating infant EEG power (Brito et al., 2017; Gabard-Durnam et al., 2019).
1) Delta power: Delta power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 1-3.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
2) Theta power: Theta power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 4-5.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
3) Low Alpha power: Low alpha power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 6-8.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
4) High Alpha power: High alpha power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 9-12.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
5) Beta power: Beta power will be measured after a Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) of the power spectrum and defined as the mean power in the 13-24.5Hz range during resting state in infants.
6) The intercept of the power spectrum for each participant will be measured using the FOOOF toolbox. The intercept reflects a broadband offset of the aperiodic signal of the power spectrum. 
7) The slope of the power spectrum from 1-45 Hz will be assessed using the FOOOF toolbox. The slope represents the changes of the aperiodic signal over this range of frequencies.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Our main analytic plan will have three steps:
i. Step 1: Is there gamma power in infancy? We will quantify mean levels of gamma power over the scalp in infancy/toddlerhood at rest, specifically averaged over the right and left hemisphere over two frontal sites (F3, F4). We will test if frontal gamma power in infancy is significantly different from 0. We expect that frontal gamma power will be significantly different from 0. Even if it is not, there still may be meaningful individual differences in frontal gamma power (as explored in the subsequent analyses).
ii. Step 2: Examine relations between SES/early adversity and frontal gamma power in infancy/toddlerhood. 
Next, we will examine the relation between frontal gamma power and SES/adversity. Because the datasets included in this study (described in section 5 below), utilize different measures of SES/adversity, analyses will be conducted separately for each dataset. The first and third datasets will examine if there are any differences in frontal gamma power based on maternal education. In the second dataset, we will examine the relation between percent time in an institution (i.e., early adversity) and frontal gamma power. 

iii. Step 3: Examine relations between frontal gamma power and language outcomes.
Third, we will examine the relation between frontal gamma power and language development. Tests for significant correlations between frontal gamma power and the language scores for each dataset, will be conducted.
